content.raw:
Since it returned something with `id='19'` rather than `num='19'`, I suspect that you are using the parser which defaults to `'id'` as the scan ID key. That would be the case if you are using the latest release version, as opposed to the development version of pyteomics. This issue was discussed [on our mailing list](https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/pyteomics/MbCNisVtq4Q), and unfortunately there hasn't been a new release since then.

If that is the case, you should be able to get the correct result by explicitly specifying `'num'` as the ID key:


```
#!python

f.get_by_id('19', 'num')
```

... or by installing the latest pyteomics version from the repository.

If neither of those help, please share the example file and we'll look into the problem.

That would be the case if you are using the latest release version, as opposed to the development version of pyteomics. This issue was discussed on our mailing list, and unfortunately there hasn't been a new release since then.

If that is the case, you should be able to get the correct result by explicitly specifying 'num' as the ID key:

f.get_by_id('19', 'num')

... or by installing the latest pyteomics version from the repository.

If neither of those help, please share the example file and we'll look into the problem.
